author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Bill Nye Is Still Having Fun With Science
description: The former host of “Bill Nye the Science Guy” has new fans on TikTok and a side gig as a celebrity pitchman.
content: Bill Nye was geeking out in his sunny apartment in uptown Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Ives
title: Celebrities Are Endorsing Covid Vaccines. Does It Help?
description: Some celebrity vaccine endorsements have delighted social media users. But epidemiologists say there isn’t much evidence proving that they boost vaccine uptake.
content: Pelé, Dolly Parton and the Dalai Lama have little in common apart from this: Over a few days in March, they became the latest celebrity case studies for the health benefits of Covid-19 vaccines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Three Colorado Officers Resign After Arrest of Woman With Dementia
description: Body-camera footage of the arrest of Karen Garner has drawn widespread outrage, as has another video that showed officers laughing at the footage.
content: Three members of a Colorado police department have resigned after they arrested and booked a 73-year-old woman with dementia who was thrown to the ground and handcuffed after she was suspected of shoplifting, officials said on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Campbell Robertson and Nicholas Fandos
title: Biden’s Expansive Infrastructure Plan Hits Close to Home for McConnell
description: President Biden’s infrastructure plan could fund a long-overdue revamp of the Brent Spence Bridge between Ohio and Kentucky. But the Senate Republican leader opposes it.
content: CINCINNATI — Early one November morning last year, a tractor-trailer hauling potassium hydroxide crashed into another truck that had jackknifed on the Brent Spence Bridge, igniting an enormous fire over the Ohio River that shut down the antiquated span connecting Cincinnati and northern Kentucky for six weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Glueck
title: As New York City Reopens, Its Recovery Will Hinge on the Next Mayor
description: The Democratic candidates are making radically different bets about the mood and priorities of New Yorkers as the city moves toward reopening after the pandemic.
content: The signs of New York City’s recovery are everywhere: Vaccinations are on the rise; restaurant and bar curfews are ending; occupancy restrictions are easing in offices, ballparks and gyms. By July 1, Mayor Bill de Blasio says the city should be “fully reopened.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: At this Derby party house, everyone is ‘like family.’
description: An unassuming house across from Churchill Downs that was once owned by a member of the band Pavement welcomes racegoers and celebrities alike.
content: If walls could talk, this unassuming house on Central Avenue, whose view from the porch perfectly frames Churchill Downs’s iconic Twin Spires, would have plenty of stories to tell.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Genzlinger
title: James Prigoff, Who Documented Street Art, Dies at 93
description: In thousands of pictures, Mr. Prigoff captured the often ephemeral but complex works that were once dismissed as vandalism.
content: James Prigoff, who after beginning his career in business turned his attention to photography, documenting public murals and street art in thousands of pictures taken all over the world and helping to legitimize works once dismissed as vandalism, died on April 21 at his home in Sacramento, Calif. He was 93.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clay Risen
title: Jeff Fox, 52, Dies; Balanced Baseball With Protecting Presidents
description: A star college athlete who later worked in the Secret Service, he played for decades in elite amateur leagues around Washington. He died of Covid-19.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joe Drape
title: Medina Spirit Wins the 147th Kentucky Derby
description: The trainer Bob Baffert collected his seventh Derby victory while the favorite, Essential Quality, faltered and finished fourth.
content: LOUISVILLE, Ky. — On another first Saturday in May, the beauty of America’s oldest sport battled neck and neck down the stretch with its unseemliness as a colt named Medina Spirit elegantly held off a determined challenge from Mandaloun.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Livia Albeck-Ripka and Matthew Abbott
title: Netflix Chronicles Byron Bay’s ‘Hot Instagrammers.’ Will Paradise Survive?
description: Tensions between protecting and capitalizing on the image of the famous Australian beach town have exploded over a new reality show.
content: BYRON BAY, Australia — The moral quandaries of life as an Instagram influencer in the famously idyllic town of Byron Bay are not lost on Ruby Tuesday Matthews.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Shpigel
title: Tom Brady Charted a New Path. Aaron Rodgers Struggles to Do the Same.
description: When Super Bowl-winning quarterbacks like Brady, Rodgers and Russell Wilson grow frustrated with their teams, the nature of N.F.L. contracts makes it hard to scramble away. Brady ultimately succeeded by running out the clock.
content: The final contract that Tom Brady signed in New England, in August 2019, contained a clever provision that prevented the Patriots from placing a franchise or transition tag on him, ensuring that, as he desired, Brady would become a free agent after the season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kate Dwyer
title: Brie Larson Pivoted to Video
description: The Oscar-winning actress has found therapeutic refuge on YouTube.
content: Brie Larson was not at last week’s Oscars, though she won one for her acting in “Room,” about a mother in captivity, five years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danielle Braff
title: From Best Friends to Platonic Spouses
description: Some people are taking their friendships to the next level by saying “I do” to marriages without sex.
content: First came blood brothers, best friends who would solidify their bond by cutting themselves and swapping a bit of blood. Then came the tiny house besties, friends moving into adjoining tiny homes. (“Bestie Row” in Texas, for example.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian M. Rosenthal and Katie Glueck
title: Andrew Yang Promised to Create 100,000 Jobs. He Ended Up With 150.
description: Mr. Yang is running for mayor of New York City as a bold thinker and entrepreneur. But his results have been uneven.
content: The idea was as simple as it was ambitious: help struggling American cities by recruiting promising college graduates, finding them jobs at start-ups in those cities and training them to open businesses of their own.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ross Douthat
title: When Wokeness Becomes Weakness
description: It will take policy failure, not just off-putting rhetoric, for the new progressivism to doom Democrats.
content: Recently, James Carville, the unfrozen Clintonite of Democratic politics, stirred a predictable controversy by complaining about “wokeness” in an interview with Sean Illing of Vox. Everyone has a different definition of the term, but Carville’s was one you hear a lot from strategically minded Democrats: Wokeness is “faculty lounge” rhetoric, the language of elite hyper-educated progressivism, entering into mass politics in a way that turns a lot of normal people off.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bhadra Sharma
title: Nepal runs out of hospital beds as India’s outbreak spills across the border.
description: Health officials in the Himalayan nation warn of an “unmanageable” situation as infections reach levels not seen since last fall.
content: The coronavirus outbreak in India has spilled across the border into Nepal, where health officials have warned that hospital beds are unavailable, vaccines are running short and the number of new infections is rising faster than overwhelmed clinics can record them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Grimes
title: Eli Broad, Who Helped Reshape Los Angeles, Dies at 87
description: The businessman, who made a fortune in home-building and insurance, spent lavishly to try to make the city a cultural capital.
content: Eli Broad, a businessman and philanthropist whose vast fortune, extensive art collection and zeal for civic improvement helped reshape the cultural landscape of Los Angeles, died on Friday at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles. He was 87.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Screwballs
description: All’s fair in love, war and Ryan McCarty’s Saturday puzzle.
content: SATURDAY PUZZLE — Happy May, everybody! We’re in the lusty height of spring and Ryan McCarty’s grid today has a lot of romantic touches, some verging on bawdy. We are also back on the short stacks, which is fine — a staircase of seven across entries making a sequence that might fit in at a poetry slam. I think the cluing today is reasonably kind, with a few exceptions, although I think I got lucky with a couple of good guesses in the long down entries, which aren’t easy at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anita Gates
title: Olympia Dukakis, Oscar Winner for ‘Moonstruck,’ Dies at 89
description: A veteran of the stage who also had a long list of film and TV credits, she was best known for playing characters who were worldly wise and world-weary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Williamson
title: A Search for Remembrance After the Sandy Hook Massacre
description: The residents of Newtown, Conn., have approved a memorial to the children and staff killed at Sandy Hook Elementary School, but the sadness has yet to abate.
content: NEWTOWN, Conn. — In their garden this past week, Francine and David Wheeler reflected on what this town’s vote on Tuesday to build a permanent memorial to the tragedy at Sandy Hook Elementary School meant to them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Initial Impressions
description: Dan Schoenholz gets our Sunday off to a flying start.
content: SUNDAY PUZZLE — We haven’t seen Dan Schoenholz on the weekend for a few years, but he’s constructed 10 other Sunday grids in the last decade (since 2006, actually — after seeing the movie “Wordplay” and getting inspired to construct). Today’s theme is fun, definitely the kind that will make you try to think of examples. There’s also a lot of fun fill, especially in the downs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Correal and Michael Gold
title: After Years of Protests, a New Jersey County Ends Its ICE Jail Contract
description: The Essex County executive said the decision to stop holding undocumented immigrants for ICE in the county jail was based on money, not politics.
content: For years, the sprawling jail complex in Essex County, N.J., where hundreds of undocumented immigrants have been held under a contract with U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement while awaiting court hearings, has been at the center of a fierce debate over federal immigration policy that peaked during the Trump administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Rosa
title: N.J. Teacher Suspended After Calling George Floyd a ‘Criminal’
description: The New Jersey high school teacher, Howard Zlotkin, has been suspended with pay after appearing to target Black students in an online class.
content: Students at a New Jersey high school logged into their remote landscape and design class on Wednesday morning expecting their teacher to lead a discussion about climate change. Instead, the teacher went on an expletive-filled, racist rant against Black Lives Matter and George Floyd, the man murdered by a Minneapolis police officer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Cook for Your Cravings
description: Whether you want something cozy and comforting, or something bright and herbaceous, we have a recipe for you.
content: When the weather is in flux, and breezy, 50-degree days are followed by humid, 80-degree ones, cravings turn on a dime. On a cool Tuesday evening, you may still want something cooked low and slow, like Sarah DiGregorio’s slow cooker chicken ragù with herbed ricotta (above) or Yasmin Fahr’s braised lemon-saffron chicken and potatoes. But on a warm Saturday, Yewande Komolafe’s garlic chicken with bright and tangy guasacaca sauce and Melissa Clark’s caramelized summer fruit tart may be more welcome dishes. Whatever the weather, there’s plenty to choose from in this week’s collection of our most popular recipes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dan Levin
title: Pandemic restrictions on foreign seasonal workers could crimp the U.S. summer.
description: Small business and industry groups are pressuring the Biden administration to relax international travel restrictions and visa application protocols.
content: With the U.S. summer tourist season looming and vaccinations gathering steam, summer camps, amusement parks, beachside hotels and restaurants — anticipating an influx of visitors — are confronting a dramatic shortage of seasonal workers. It is threatening to sabotage their best efforts to stay financially afloat after more than a year of pandemic-fueled economic hardship.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Kristof
title: Joe Biden Is Electrifying America Like F.D.R.
description: My hometown in Oregon shows what the federal government can do — and also what happens when it stops trying.
content: YAMHILL, Ore. — The best argument for President Biden’s three-part proposal to invest heavily in America and its people is an echo of Franklin Roosevelt’s explanation for the New Deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jyoti Shelar
title: Manisha Jadhav, Key Administrator at Mumbai Hospital, Dies at 51
description: Dr. Jadhav took action when the pandemic hit last year, mustering personal protection equipment, food and transportation for the staff.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard Goldstein
title: John Konrads, ‘Wonder Boy’ Olympian Swimmer, Dies at 78
description: A Hall of Famer, he was a sensation at the 1960 Games in Rome. He and his sister Ilsa, a champion in her own right, were known as “the Konrads Kids.”
content: John Konrads, a former teenage swimming sensation for Australia who won a gold medal in the 1,500-meter freestyle at the 1960 Rome Olympics and joined with his younger sister, Ilsa, in setting numerous world records, died on April 25 in the Noosa area of eastern Australia, on the Sunshine Coast. He was 78.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maureen Dowd
title: The Jimmy Carter and Joe Biden Show
description: Two plain-spoken guys get together down in Plains.
content: WASHINGTON — Joe Biden has respect for his elders. And there aren’t that many of them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Schmidle
title: Richard Branson Wanted to Beat Elon Musk to Space. It’s Been a Wild Ride.
description: Richard Branson thought he could win the commercial space race with a relentless pursuit of perfection. But his company’s failure to launch exposed the limits of human ingenuity.
content: On the morning of Feb. 22, 2019, my two sons and I fixed our gazes on the horizon of the Mojave Desert, waiting for a flame to appear in the distant sky: Virgin Galactic’s spaceship was about to launch.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Heather Murphy
title: Hundreds Reported Abnormal Menstruation After Exposure to Tear Gas, Study Finds
description: A scientific paper expands on social media reports of sudden onset of periods, spotting and other menstrual peculiarities during last summer’s protests in Portland, Ore.
content: At some point last summer, there were just too many reports of protesters who had experienced abnormal menstrual cycles after being exposed to tear gas for Britta Torgrimson-Ojerio, a nurse researcher at the Kaiser Permanente Center for Health Research in Portland, to dismiss them as coincidence.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shawn Hubler
title: Arnold Schwarzenegger Is No Longer the Governor of California. Right?
description: Amid a pandemic and a recall, Mr. Schwarzenegger has been in demand at his Los Angeles mansion, embracing his unlikely role as California’s “elderly statesman.”
content: LOS ANGELES — Arnold Schwarzenegger settled into a big leather rocker recliner on the back patio of his mansion. His tiny rescue dog, Cherry, scampered at his feet, wearing a butterfly bow.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Richard C. Paddock and Dera Menra Sijabat
title: In Indonesia, lab workers are arrested and accused of reusing nasal swabs in thousands of coronavirus tests.
description: The authorities arrested five people and said they were investigating whether any people were infected with the coronavirus as a result of the contaminated tests given at an airport testing site.
content: The idea was simple: Why throw away used rapid antigen test kits for the coronavirus when they could be used again and again?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nossiter
title: Afghan Blast on Eve of U.S. Pullout Deadline Kills at Least 27
description: If the blast was the work of the Taliban, as the Afghan government asserts, it would be the most overt signal yet that the peace deal is off.
content: KABUL, Afghanistan — On the eve of a symbolic date for America’s withdrawal from Afghanistan, a truck laden with explosives blew up outside a guesthouse south of the capital on Friday night, killing at least 27 people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Hari Kumar, Karan Deep Singh and Sameer Yasir
title: India’s Covid crisis has tarnished Modi’s aura of political invulnerability.
description: As a vicious second coronavirus wave has made India the worst-hit country in the world, its prime minister, Narendra Modi, is at the center of a national reckoning, one that comes amid India’s stark reversal from declaring victory to suffering its gravest emergency in decades.
content: As a vicious second coronavirus wave has made India the worst-hit country in the world, its prime minister, Narendra Modi, is at the center of a national reckoning, one that comes amid India’s stark reversal from declaring victory to suffering its gravest emergency in decades.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Associated Press
title: Judge and Cole Dominate as Yankees Crush Tigers
description: Judge’s two homers held lead a blowout. The Mets, meanwhile, had tempers flare in a loss to Philadelphia.
content: Aaron Judge managed his own workload Friday night.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Joe Biden, the Reverse Ronald Reagan
description: Four decades later, another elder statesman seeks to transform Americans’ ideas about the size of government.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your wrap-up of the week in national politics. I’m Lisa Lerer, your host.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Lerer
title: Elizabeth Warren Grapples With Presidential Loss in New Book
description: In “Persist,” the Massachusetts senator delves into gender issues and her own shortcomings after her failed bid for the Democratic nomination.
content: The question came at a campaign cattle call in April 2019, just a few months after Elizabeth Warren announced her presidential bid: How would she address “the urge to flee to the safety of a white male candidate?”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sameer Yasir
title: Adar Poonawalla, head of India’s vaccine giant, speaks from London of the enormous pressure he is under.
description: The executive told The Times of London that he had arrived in Britain for “an extended time” just before travel restrictions would have blocked him. But he then tweeted he would return to India in days after business meetings.
content: In recent months, the chief executive of Serum Institute of India, the world’s largest vaccine manufacturer, has come under increasingly intense pressure as both pro-government voices and leaders of the state governments headed by opposition politicians criticized him.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: MoMA Blocks Protesters Who Planned to Demonstrate Inside
description: The museum, citing safety concerns, closed its doors to the protesters who say MoMA caters too much to the interests of its wealthy donors.
content: The Museum of Modern Art blocked protesters from entering the museum Friday afternoon at the conclusion of a march designed to focus attention on what the demonstrators say is the undue influence of wealthy patrons on the cultural institution’s values and programming.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: Should Young Americans Be Required to Give a Year of Service?
description: A year of teamwork could help bridge our social divides.
content: American presidents have long vied to echo John Kennedy’s “Ask not what your country can do for you.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Rappeport
title: Pandemic Inspector General Warns of Oversight Breakdown
description: An internal dispute at the Treasury Department shows the challenge of tracking trillions of dollars of economic relief money.
content: WASHINGTON — A breakdown in the oversight of trillions of dollars of economic relief money spilled into public view on Friday night when the Treasury Department’s special inspector general for pandemic recovery said in a report that his powers to scrutinize funds had been curtailed this week after a decision by the Justice Department’s Office of Legal Counsel.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: ‘Every Time I’m Calling, Someone Has Died’: The Anguish of India’s Diaspora
description: In WhatsApp chats, video calls, Facebook groups and forums, a global community has scrambled to save, and sometimes mourn, Covid-stricken loved ones.
content: LONDON — First, there was the scramble to find her father a bed in intensive care. Then came the price gouging for an all but impossible to find therapeutic injection. And, through it all, countless hours on the phone with doctors, family and friends dealing with logistical problems.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Soul-Searching in Israel After Deadly Stampede at Religious Site
description: Quotation of the Day for Saturday, May 1, 2021.
content: “It’s been one blow after another. It’s something we don’t know how to pick ourselves up from.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Conor Dougherty
title: Why a $10,000 Tax Deduction Could Hold Up Trillions in Stimulus Funds
description: The fight over SALT is a case study in the age-old conflict between constituent politics and national policy.
content: In 2017, congressional Republicans capped a tax break that benefits America’s highest-earning households and people with multimillion-dollar homes. Coastal Democrats have been trying to get it back ever since.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Hoppert
title: Malathaat won the Kentucky Oaks and could meet the boys in the Belmont.
description: The favorite Malathaat won the Kentucky Oaks by a neck at Churchill Downs on Friday, and her connections are not ruling out a matchup against the boys in the Belmont.
content: The 5-2 favorite Malathaat, ridden by John Velazquez, held off Search Results to win the Kentucky Oaks by a neck at Churchill Downs on Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
title: Decorating Scandal Engulfs Boris Johnson and Puts Fiancée in Spotlight
description: Critics see the hand of Carrie Symonds in the costly makeover of the couple’s apartment and other political dust-ups. Supporters see “outdated sexist tropes.”
content: LONDON — Of all the unsavory ethical questions swirling around Prime Minister Boris Johnson these days, the one that has stuck is how he paid for the costly makeover of his apartment in Downing Street. And it has put his 33-year-old fiancée, Carrie Symonds, under a particularly scorching spotlight.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard, Farnaz Fassihi and Jane Arraf
title: Fierce Foes, Iran and Saudi Arabia Secretly Explore Defusing Tensions
description: Talks between the two regional powers, if successful, could start to lower the temperature on several conflicts across the Middle East.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — In a prime-time television interview four years ago, Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman of Saudi Arabia dismissed the idea that his kingdom could somehow find an accommodation with its archrival, Iran.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Clifford Krauss
title: Venezuela Releases 6 U.S. Oil Executives to House Arrest
description: The group, known as the “Citgo 6,” has been held on corruption charges. Their release may be a sign that Venezuela would like to improve relations with the Biden administration.
content: HOUSTON — The Venezuelan government released a group of American refinery executives from prison to house arrest in Caracas on Friday, in a possible sign that President Nicolás Maduro would like to improve relations with the Biden administration.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Savage
title: Trump’s Secret Rules for Drone Strikes Outside War Zones Are Disclosed
description: The release of the 2017 policy — with redactions — stemmed from open-records lawsuits by The Times and the A.C.L.U.
content: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration has disclosed a set of rules secretly issued by President Donald J. Trump in 2017 for counterterrorism “direct action” operations — like drone strikes and commando raids outside conventional war zones — which the White House has suspended as it weighs whether and how to tighten the guidelines.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Anna Sale
title: How to Make Your Small Talk Big
description: As we emerge from social isolation, there are ways to make our conversations richer and deeper.
content: We’ve forgotten how to talk to people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: Oregon Lawmaker Who Let Protesters Into State Capitol Is Charged in Breach
description: Surveillance footage shows State Representative Mike Nearman opening a door to let protesters into the Capitol, in Salem, last year.
content: A Republican state legislator from Oregon who was captured on surveillance video allowing demonstrators to enter the State Capitol in December was charged on Friday in connection with the breach of the building, which led to a conflict between officers and protesters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caitlin Lovinger
title: Variety: Vowel-less Crossword
description: Jst whn w wr strtng t fl smrt, vn Klsh stps b wth chllng.
content: VOWEL-LESS CROSSWORD — This occasional variety puzzle is self-explanatory and, really, oh-so-challenging. This is the first time I’ve seen one by Evan Kalish, an excellent and very funny constructor who usually works with themes, and I think I can get a taste of his sense of humor in this grid, but it might just be that several entries hit my funny bone.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael J. de la Merced and Mary Williams Walsh
title: Berkshire Hathaway Shows a Rebound From the Pandemic
description: Warren Buffett was upbeat about his company’s increase in earnings in the first quarter. And, at the shareholders’ meeting, he defended Berkshire’s efforts on dealing with climate change.
content: Berkshire Hathaway, the conglomerate run by Warren E. Buffett, reported $11.7 billion in net earnings in the first quarter on Saturday, swinging to a profit from a $49.7 billion loss a year ago as the paper value of its investment gains soared.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Morales
title: Horse Fossil, Possibly From the Ice Age, Is Found in a Las Vegas Backyard
description: Workers found the bones, which could be up to 14,000 years old, during the construction of a pool.
content: While digging in Matthew Perkins’s backyard last week in Las Vegas to build a pool, construction workers made an unexpected discovery: bones buried about five feet deep in the soil.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: G.O.P. Seeks to Empower Poll Watchers, Raising Intimidation Worries
description: Republicans in several states are pushing bills to give poll watchers more autonomy. Alarmed election officials and voting rights activists say it’s a new attempt to target voters of color.
content: HOUSTON — The red dot of a laser pointer circled downtown Houston on a map during a virtual training of poll watchers by the Harris County Republican Party. It highlighted densely populated, largely Black, Latino and Asian neighborhoods.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patrick Kingsley
title: Recriminations Intensify After Deadly Israel Stampede
description: The deaths of 45 pilgrims at a Jewish holy site prompted a wave of national unity, but there were also growing calls for accountability.
content: MOUNT MERON, Israel — Demands for accountability after a disaster that left 45 people dead at a holy site in northern Israel mounted on Saturday as questions swirled about the culpability of the government, religious leaders and the police.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Bruni
title: The New Trump? Easy. It’s Tucker.
description: You don’t just give your detractors agita. You give them material.
content: The lead item in Politico’s signature morning newsletter asked if a certain public figure was “losing his mind.” His rants made him seem ever “more unhinged.” Then again, they might be theatrical, a way to “keep you guessing as to whether he’s just putting you on.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dave Montgomery and Edgar Sandoval
title: 23 Candidates Are on Ballot for Open Texas Congressional Seat
description: The front-runner in Saturday’s election is Susan Wright, who has been endorsed by Donald J. Trump and is the widow of Representative Ron Wright, who died of Covid-19 in February.
content: AUSTIN, Texas — Not long ago, Texas’ Sixth Congressional District seemed to be securely in Republican hands. Ron Wright, a member of the conservative House Freedom Caucus, was poised to advance the G.O.P.’s agenda after he was elected in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ronda Kaysen
title: Should You Renovate the Kitchen Before You Sell?
description: One outdated room can stand out and hurt a sale. But before you do any last-minute work, set a budget and make sure you finish what you start.
content: Q: My partner and I are unexpectedly moving out of state this fall and need to sell our Westchester, N.Y., house. When we bought it five years ago, it hadn’t been renovated in decades. We’ve updated every room except the kitchen, which has old vinyl floors, stained Formica countertops and outdated cabinets. What should we do? My partner thinks if we don’t renovate it, we’ll lose money on the sale. But that seems like a huge headache — and expense — especially right now. What do you think?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deborah Needleman
title: Looking for a Weekend Excursion? Try Craft Shop Hopping
description: A wealth of stores and studios in Connecticut and upstate New York offer lovely handmade wares that you’ll have forever.
content: When I heard that Creel and Gow, the beloved cabinet of antique and handmade curiosities on Manhattan’s Upper East Side, just opened an outpost in Millbrook, N.Y., in order to have more space for its handcrafted furniture and textiles made by artisans in Morocco, where its owners, Jamie Creel and Marco Scarani, live for part of the year, it occurred to me that the area around Millbrook and in nearby Litchfield County, Conn., has become a mecca for craft. Not the chunky or cheeky minimalist Brooklynite-gone-upstate kind of craft, but the kind made by highly skilled longstanding practitioners, whose wares look most at home when paired with fine old patinated things. These sorts of history-friendly creations are the domain of people like Creel and Scarani — shopkeepers (and decorators and antiques dealers) who make keeping a shop seem like an art.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Newsmax Apologizes for False Claims of Vote-Rigging by a Dominion Employee
description: The right-wing news site said it had found “no evidence” for pro-Trump conspiracy theories about Eric Coomer, who was Dominion’s director of product strategy and security.
content: The conservative news outlet Newsmax formally apologized on Friday for spreading baseless allegations that an employee of Dominion Voting Systems had rigged voting machines in an effort to sink President Donald J. Trump’s bid for re-election last year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Destin Jenkins
title: What History Can Teach Banks About Making Change
description: Financial institutions have a unique power to contribute to social movements — if they choose to use it.
content: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in the news. If you don’t already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil MacFarquhar
title: From the Past, a Chilling Warning About the Extremists of the Present
description: Almost four decades after officials dismantled the Order, a violent far-right group, experts see echoes in the far right of today.
content: They robbed an armored car outside a sprawling Seattle shopping mall.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abigail Tucker
title: Whale Mothers Need Their Moms. So Do I.
description: Scientists have found intergenerational care may be the key to thriving mothers, and children.
content: When I first became a mother a decade ago, I lived 282 miles from my mom, on a block full of clueless new parents like me — formerly competent adults who now found ourselves calling the fire department because our toddlers had locked us out again, or because we’d set our homes ablaze in a diligent effort to sterilize pacifiers on the stove. (We called this a “paci-fire.”)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madeleine Ngo
title: Manchin says he won’t support a D.C. statehood bill.
description: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, told local news reporters that he believed making Washington, D.C., a state would require a constitutional amendment.
content: Senator Joe Manchin III, Democrat of West Virginia, told local news reporters on Friday that he would not support a bill to grant statehood to Washington, D.C., saying he believed a constitutional amendment was needed instead of legislation.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Taylor Lorenz
title: Digital Horses Are the Talk of the Crypto World
description: Horse racing meet NFT mania on Zed Run, a digital platform where some top steeds are fetching six-figure sums.
content: The Kentucky Derby may be the best-known stakes race happening in the equestrian world this weekend, but it’s hardly the only one.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Levenson
title: Linfield University Fires Professor Who Spoke Out About Misconduct Cases
description: Allegations of anti-Semitism, sexual misconduct and racial discrimination have led to turmoil on the small Oregon campus. Some have called for the university’s president to resign.
content: Across the country, colleges and universities have been wrestling with allegations of sexual misconduct, racial discrimination and anti-Semitism. But rarely have the three collided at the highest levels of leadership, as they have at Linfield University, a small, historically Baptist college in Oregon’s wine country, which celebrated the appointment of its first Black president in 2018.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman, Hari Kumar, Karan Deep Singh and Sameer Yasir
title: India’s Covid-19 Crisis Shakes Modi’s Image of Strength
description: Overconfidence and missteps contributed to the country’s devastating second wave, his critics say, tarnishing the prime minister’s aura of political invulnerability.
content: NEW DELHI — His Covid-19 task force didn’t meet for months. His health minister assured the public in March that India had reached the pandemic’s “endgame.” A few weeks before that, Prime Minister Narendra Modi boasted to global leaders that his nation had triumphed over the coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: May Vocabulary Challenge
description: How many of our recent Words of the Day can you use correctly in a 50-word story? Send us yours by May 15. And check out the winners of our April challenge!
content: Note: Outstanding entries to our April Vocabulary Challenge are recognized at the bottom of this post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lazaro Gamio and Alexandria Symonds
title: Global Virus Cases Reach New Peak, Driven by India and South America
description: Led by surges in the two hotspots and Eastern Europe, the average number of new daily cases has exceeded 800,000 for more than a week.
content: Led by surges in the two hotspots and Eastern Europe, the average number of new daily cases has exceeded 800,000 for more than a week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Denise Lu
title: It Only Takes a Few People to Change Your State’s Congressional Seats
description: States can lose a House seat over a small number of people. In the case of New York, the number would fit in a single subway car. Take a look at other record margins that altered congressional representation.
content: States can lose a House seat over a small number of people. In the case of New York, the number would fit in a single subway car. Take a look at other record margins that altered congressional representation.

title: In a Pandemic, Finding Comfort in the Arts
description: Watching “Gilmore Girls,” campily performing play readings and writing poetry have been therapeutic for readers.

title: Corrections: May 1, 2021
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Saturday, May 1, 2021.
content: An article on Friday about the expansion of a law in Germany aimed at reducing carbon emissions misstated the title of Peter Altmaier. He is the economy minister, not the finance minister.
source.name: The New York Times

title: A Year of ‘Languishing’ and ‘Fallow Space’
description: “Languishing definitely describes the lack of interest I feel just now,” one reader writes. Another describes a fallow period of rest preparing for what comes next.

title: Covid Isolation: A Reprieve From the Stresses of Racism
description: A Black man relates how his body relaxed as he mostly stayed indoors, but tensions returned as he began venturing out and encountering everyday racial bias.
